body:
This is a great idea, but would break existing specs that are phrased like this: 
describe Object, :method do

Is that officially supported?  Or just that RSpec calls `#to_s` on additional arguments passed to `describe`, so people have been able to use symbols before?

Maybe it can be considered for a 3.0 release? (which would imply it may have breaking changes)

It is officially supported for backward compatibility, though I'd just as soon not document it as not to encourage people to use it :)

Yes, can consider for a 3.0 release, but I don't want to do that very soon.
I'd also like to get some feedback from more people - want to see if anybody really relies on this behavior.

+1

Every single metadata that I've used has a `true` value.

+1

I really like this idea. I've also never used a value different from `true`.

I've never used the case David gives 

describe Object, :method

probably because this is the first I've heard of it <G>.

So it wouldn't bother me if this went into RSpec 2

OTOH, perhaps a slightly different approach

describe "something", tags(:slow, :focus, :issue => '79')

where we had the following method defined in the right place.

def tags(*symbols, options={})
   {}.tap {|hash|
     symbols.each {||sym| hash[sym] = true}
   }.merge(options)
end

The actual name of the 'helper' method isn't important, and I'm not sure that tags is the write choice, but it's short enough that 

tags(:slow)

is marginally shorter than

:slow => true

Just a thought.

Also I'm pretty sure that whether this is done via a 'tags helper' or directly in describe that mixed metadata would need to be given with the symbols first followed by any hash values.

@rubyredrick--interesting idea. I'm not sure that `tags` is the right name for the helper, though--everywhere else, we call the hash "metadata", not "tags". One other idea...how about a configuration option: 
RSpec.configure |c|
  c.treat_symbols_as_metadata_keys_with_true_values = true
end
(Note that I'm not at all sold on the name; can anyone else think of a better name that's clear about what it does?) By default, the option would be false. When it's false, and a symbol is encountered in the args list for `#describe` or `#context`, it would print a deprecation warning. This would allow cases like `describe Object, :method` to still work while providing an appropriate warning so users know that behavior will be removed in a future version (presumably 3.0).

It's called tag on the command line in order to align with Cucumber's tag API.

I'd be OK with the config option as a means of introducing this before 3.0, but in the long run I'd prefer that the option goes away and everything after the initial string is considered metadata.

I've just pushed this into the [304-less-verbose-metadata](https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/commits/304-less-verbose-metadata/) branch. I'm not totally sold on the configuration option name--it's very explicit but a bit long, I think. @dchelimsky: I definitely don't want this option to stick around long term. Let's plan to remove the option in the 3.0 release--since that's a major version bump, it can include breaking changes, and it's a pretty painless breaking change. Those that use this option will just have to remove one line of code. What do you think about updating the generator in rspec-rails so that the spec_helper.rb it generates sets this option to true by default? Maybe even do a version check: 
RSpec.configure |c|
  c.treat_symbols_as_metadata_keys_with_true_values = true if RSpec::Core::VERSION =~ /^3/
end
I'm more inclined to deprecate it in 3.0 (with a deprecation warning stating that it has no effect) and remove it in 4.0. I want to avoid breakage as much as possible, even in major releases. WDYT?

> I'm more inclined to deprecate it in 3.0 (with a deprecation warning stating that it has no effect) and remove it in 4.0. I want to avoid breakage as much as possible, even in major releases. WDYT?

Sounds great.  That was actually my initial thought until you said "in the long run I'd prefer that the option goes away"...and with the path you've outlined, we'll be keeping the option (or at least a deprecation stub) until 4.0.  Which could be a very long time from now...

Anyhow, I've merged this (with a few copy/paste errors fixed) into master.

Should we add support for this to the various configuration options that take a metadata hash?  Currently it's only working for metadata passed to `describe`, `context` or `it`.  I was thinking a bit more about this yesterday and realized that it might be confusing if you can't use this feature for `config.before`, `config.include`, etc.

Thoughts?
Yes. I'd definitely like to align the API's on all of these.

OK, I've updated the following so they can use symbols:
- `config.before`
- `config.after`
- `config.around`
- `config.filter_run`
- `config.filter_run_excluding`
- `config.include`
- `config.extend`
- `config.alias_example_to`
- `config.for_groups_matching`

I think I got them all, but let me know if I missed any.
